EC: Epichlorohydrin. BGE: Butyl glycidyl ether. Acidic pyridinium ionic liquid: an efficient bifunctional organocatalyst to synthesis carbonate from atmospheric CO2 and epoxide. Fereshteh Norouzi Methodology Software Writing – original draft Data curation Visualization Investigation Amir Abdolmaleki Supervision Conceptualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz, 71467-13565, Iran Department of Chemistry School of Sciences Shiraz University Shiraz 71467-13565 Iran Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz, 71467-13565, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author Ionic liquids (ILs) are used as non-toxic, biodegradable, non-volatile, and relatively low-cost catalysts to synthesize 5-membered cyclic organic carbonates (COCs) from carbon dioxide (CO2) and different types of oxiranes in great conversion and selectivity. Single-component IL containing pyridinium salt moieties as quaternary amine, the carboxylic functional group as a H-bond donor, and bromine as a nucleophile and significant leaving group was synthesized by a simple method. The simultaneous selection and use of all mentioned factors in IL caused the epoxides converted into their corresponding carbonates under mild conditions, under 1 atm carbon dioxide (CO2) pressure (CO2 balloon), co-catalyst/ metal/ and solvent-free during 2.5 h. The synthetic catalyst converted styrene oxide (SO) to styrene carbonate (SC) with 100% conversion and selectivity. Moreover, the catalyst could be recycled more than four times before losing its remarkable catalytic activity. Finally, an inferential mechanism was suggested according to the experimental results. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Carbonates pyridinium ionic liquid Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Improving the rising generation's lives depends to a large extent on more sensible management of resources. The current level of this management still needs extra improvement as it is far from the ideal level. To date, natural gas, coal, and crude oil are remarkable carbon resources. Therefore, renewable carbon dioxide can be another suitable source of carbon to the reduction of the carbon footprint. CO2 is one of the most available greenhouse gases, which is increasing rapidly and causes climate crisis, rising ocean surface, and extreme weather events [1]. Subsequently, more efforts have been made to use this abundant, inexpensive, non-toxic, and stable gas. CO2 is widely used in the industry in preparation and food packaging, fire extinguishers, producing many types of cooling tools and laser devices [2–4]. On the other hand, on small scale, many attempts have been made to turn CO2 into more valuable chemical compounds as it is the main source of C1, CO, and CO2 [5–8] or prevent more production in chemical process [9,10]. However, the biggest problem with CO2 fixation is its thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia [11]. Hence, it is very important to develop simple, inexpensive, and effective catalysts to overcome these problems for successful CO2 fixation. One of the most recent atomic economies of CO2 utilization is the insertion of CO2 into epoxide to produce COCs with reduced carbon footprint according to scheme 1 [12]. Carbonates are valuable chemical compounds that are used as monomers of polycarbonates and polyurethanes [13], electrolytes in batteries [14], and polar aprotic solvents [15]. Over the last two decades, various catalysts including metallic and non-metallic complexes, IL and deep eutectic solvents, functionalized polymers, and molecular sieves have been designed and manufactured for the synthesis of carbonates using CO2 [16,17]. All the mentioned catalysts have particular advantages and disadvantages. In particular, due to the high price of metals and their environmental problems, it is preferred to intercept their use as catalysts in organic reactions [18,19]. Special attention has been given to ILs in recent decades due to their low vapor pressure and thermal stability. One of the most important IL features as a catalyst in carbonate synthesis is that they do not require metal, co-catalyst, or solvent [20–22]. It has been reported that several ILs, including quaternary phosphonium [23], pyrazolium [24,25], pyridinium [26], morpholinium [27], imidazolium [28], quaternary ammonium [29], can be used to synthesize carbonates from CO2 and oxirane. Although the advantages of ILs are well known, it is very substantial to synthesize ILs that carry out the reactions under mild conditions, show great efficiency in the absence of a co-catalyst, and be weather insensitive. Although pyridinium ILs are less expensive compared to imidazolium ILs, pyridinium ILs have been used less due to their lower diversity, in cycloaddition COCs synthesis. According to previous reports [30], it understood that pyridinium ILs are appreciably competitive with imidazolium ILs, even in some cases they have been much more efficient. Meanwhile, according to experimental and theoretical studies, it has been determined that hydrogen bonding greatly increases the IL's efficiency in COCs reactions [31,32]. Accordingly, it is very important to design a stable [33] bifunctional and single-component IL catalyst consisting of pyridinium and acidic parts which promote the conversion of oxiranes to carbonates under mild conditions under 1 atm CO2 with high efficiency. 4-(Dimethylamino) pyridine (DMAP) is one of the famous pyridine derivatives that has been used as a co-catalyst [34] and Lewis's base [35] in the formation of COCs. Furthermore, the excellent structure of DMAP in positive charge delocalization has made it a suitable option among pyridinium derivatives. Herein, 1-(carboxy methyl) 4-(dimethyl amino) pyridinium bromide [CMDMAPy]Br IL (Scheme 2) was prepared and used as catalysts to synthesize COCs. Although this IL does not have any functional group to react with CO2 chemically, due to its unique structure, it absorbs CO2 from different sites through weak physical forces (electrostatic interaction). In general, carbonyl groups act as CO2 absorbents. Carbonyl oxygen, as a Lewis base, can interact physically with the central carbon C of CO2, as well as carboxylic acid hydrogen can interact with one of the oxygens of CO2 through a hydrogen bond. On the other hand, some literature reported that the π-π interaction of an aromatic with a non-aromatic monomer is stronger than the interaction between two aromatics [36], so the DMAP ring also can probably absorb CO2 through π-π interaction. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 General Synthetic Procedure for [CMDMAPy]Br The IL salt was synthesized according to the methods 1 in the previous work [30]. In a 50 mL round bottom flask, 50 mmol (6.94 g) of bromoacetic acid was dissolved in 3 mL of ethanol in an ice bath. In the ice bath, 5 mL ethanol solution containing 50 mmol (6.10 g) of DMAP was added over 1 h to the above mixture and stirred for 1.5 h. Then the mixture refluxed for 6 h, which caused the white precipitate formation. The solvent was evaporated from the mixture by distillation under a vacuum. After cooling the remaining liquid, white crystals formed, which dried at room temperature after filtering and washing with ethanol. The final product was kept in a closed container to avoid absorbing moisture. 2.2 Chemical rection of 1 atm CO2 with styrene epoxide The fixation reaction of CO2 into oxirane was accomplished in a 15 mL test tube equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a CO2 balloon. 3 mmol of epoxide and 0.2 mol% of IL were added to the test tube without using any co-catalyst or solvents. The balloon was filled with CO2, sealed, and the test tube was placed in a preheated oil bath at 90 ˚C for 2.5 h. Then the test tube was cooled, and the reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate and water to separate the catalyst. The organic phase was separated and analyzed by GC (Agilent 7890A with HP1 column). Column chromatography with ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (3:7 v/v) mixture as elution solvent was used to purify COCs. The carbonate products were characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Most of the synthesized carbonate products were liquid and light yellow. 3 Results and discussion Pyridinium ILs have previously been demonstrated to be highly effective in synthesizing COCs [30]. To improve the conditions of earlier work, a new pyridinium IL has been synthesized and compared with previously used IL. A simple alkylation method was used to synthesize [CMDMAPy]Br IL, which was used under solvent-free conditions in the synthesis of SC without any co-catalysts. 3.1 Characterization of catalyst [CMDMAPy]Br was analyzed using FT-IR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR (see Supporting Information). For the [CMDMAPy]Br catalyst, a chemical shift of deshielded methylene (-CH2) protons appeared between 4.5-5.0 ppm due to its position between the positive nitrogen and the electron-withdrawing carboxylic acid group. The hydrogens of methyl (-CH3) groups were more deshielded compared to pure DMAP due to the delocalized positive charge and appeared at 3.1 ppm (Fig S1). The presence of a carboxylic acid functional group in the synthesized IL was confirmed by FT-IR, and appeared as a broad peak at 3300 cm−1 (Fig S3). The peaks in the region of 1706-1790 cm−1 were related to the carbonyl (C=O) IL group. 3.2 Investigate different reaction conditions Styrene oxide as a stable epoxide was used as a model reactant in the CO2 insertion into the epoxide reaction. For the prediction of optimal conditions, various reaction parameters such as, time, catalyst amount, temperature, and solvent were tested under 1 atm CO2 balloon conditions. The results are shown in Table 1 and Fig 1 . SO did not convert into its corresponding SC even after 12 h in the absence of [CMDMAPy]Br IL at 90 ˚C (Table 1, Entry 1). This means that the inherent reactivity of epoxide is not sufficient to interact with stable CO2 and this reaction requires the presence of a catalyst. A 0.1 mol% [CMDMAPy]Br catalyst was initially used to investigate the effect of reaction time on SC conversion and selectivity. SC yield increased sharply during 2.5 h and reached 98%. As the reaction time increased, the yield grew slowly. Furthermore, in a time longer than 2.5 h, the yield did not change noticeably. The SC selectivity was about 99% after 2.5 h (Table 1, Entries 2-4 and Fig 1). Then, the amount of IL in the formation of SC was investigated. As shown in Fig 1, different amounts of [CMDMAPy]Br promoted the SC formation reaction with excellent selectivity, while the previous ionic liquid ([CMPy]Br) [28] had less selectivity, the time intervals and the amount of IL did not have a significant effect on the selectivity. The conversion of SC increased gradually by increasing the catalyst amount from 0.1 to 0.3 mol% (Table 1, Entries 2-8). Excellent conversion (100%) and selectivity (100%) were observed in the presence of 0.2 mol% [CMDMAPy]Br during 2.5 h at 90 ˚C (Entry 6). A catalyst amount of 0.2 mol% was found to be the optimal catalyst amount as there was no significant difference in reaction time with 0.3 mol%. In the next step, the temperature efficiency on the conversion and selectivity of the SC formation was studied (Table 1, Entries 9-12). It was found that SC was hardly formed at ambient temperature up to 60 ˚C and the conversion was less than 20% at 60 ˚C under solvent-free conditions (Entry 10). The reaction conversion increased intensely from 80 ˚C to 90 ˚C. The temperature increasing up to 90 ˚C leads to a decrease in the IL's viscosity, and the decrease in viscosity has a significant effect on the dissolution and uptake of CO2. Indeed, the time taken for the dissolution of the IL with the substrate was greatly reduced, subsequently decreased the total reaction time. Therefore, the most suitable reaction conditions for converting SO to SC using [CMDMAPy]Br included: 0.2 mol% [CMDMAPy]Br, 90 ˚C, and 2.5 h. Also, several green solvents were used in the SC formation under optimal conditions and their effects were investigated (Table 1, Entries 13-15). The results indicated that the higher polarity of the organic solvent increased the conversion and subsequently the selectivity of products. Therefore, among the organic green solvents used in the SC formation reaction, methanol was the most efficient. As can be seen, the reaction progressed well to 98% in the presence of methanol at 65 ˚C (Entry 15), and the conversion has greatly increased compared to the solvent-free conditions at 65 ˚C (Entry 10). Considering the lower conversion of reaction (98%, Entry 15) in the presence of methanol compared to the solvent-free condition (100%, Entry 6) and the toxicity of methanol, the solvent-free was chosen as the best condition. Certainly, according to the desired conditions and mandatory lower temperature, methanol can be chosen as a good solvent. To determine the effect of pure CO2 on the synthesis of COCs, the reaction was performed under optimal conditions, without a CO2 balloon and in contact with atmospheric air (Table 1, Entry 16). Eventually, the best conditions of reaction for the conversion of SO and CO2 into SC were determined as solvent-free, CO2 balloon, 0.2 mol% [CMDMAPy]Br as the catalyst, at 90 ˚C, and in 2.5 h (all the conditions were repeated at least 2 times). To evaluate the applicability of [CMDMAPy]Br, the reaction was scaled up to 60 mmol (Table 1, Entry 17). The results showed that the conversion of SC did not change significantly, which means that the [CMDMAPy]Br can be used for CO2 fixation on a larger scale. 3.3 The reusability of the catalyst One of the most important features of green catalysts used in industry is their ability to be recycled and reused. The reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate and water after the completion of the reaction. The aqueous phase containing the catalyst was separated from the organic phase containing the cyclic carbonate and by-products. The water of the aqueous phase was evaporated by a rotary evaporator and the remaining IL was collected and used in subsequent reactions without further purification. The recycled catalyst was used in 4 consecutive reactions under optimal conditions (SO 3 mmol, 0.2 mol% [CMDMAPy]Br, 90 ˚C, 2.5 h, and 1 atm CO2 balloons) (Fig 2 ). After four reuses, carbonate's conversion and selectivity decreased slightly, but remained above 90%. 3.4 Synthesis of other carbonate derivatives To study the efficiency of bifunctional IL catalysts based on [CMDMAPy]Br, it was used in CO2 fixation into different epoxides and the obtained results are shown in Table 2 . [CMDMAPy]Br as an efficient IL catalyst for most of the oxiranes (Table 2, row 4-7), converted them to their corresponding cyclic carbonates with conversion above 90%. As reported in Table 2, the reaction's yield reduced as the polarity of epoxides decreased (Entries 8,9). There was no notable change in the reaction's yield by extending the reaction time to 5 h. 3.5 A suggested mechanism for the chemical fixation of CO2 to oxiranes Based on previous experimental and theoretical studies [37,38], a possible mechanism for the formation of COCs from oxirane and CO2 was suggested (Scheme 3 ). In the first step, the epoxides molecule become more active by the coordination of the H atom of carboxylic acid (or any other acidic site) with the O atom of oxirane through a H-bond and then three-membered epoxide ring is attacked by bromine from the less hindered side causes the opening of the epoxides ring. If H2O molecules are present in the reaction medium, the oxygen anion may react with the H2O and eventually produces the corresponding diol as a by-product, otherwise the oxygen anion interacts with the CO2 molecule (physically interacted with the IL) and an alkyl carbonate anion intermediate is formed. It should be noted that due to the unique structure of this synthesized IL and its ability to delocalize the positive charge, the intermediate is less sensitive to the presence of H2O than [CMPy]Br, so the by-product was rarely observed. Thereupon, the synthesized alkyl carbonate anion will remove the bromine by the intramolecular substitution reaction to form the carbonate product. 3.6 A short review on the earlier works The comparison of a number of pyridinium-based IL catalysts made it clear that several factors affect the reaction's condition, such as the type of acidic hydrogen, counter ion, substitution of the pyridinium group, and eventually the length of the alkyl chain. As shown in Table 3 , non-protic pyridinium ILs converted epoxides to carbonates in the presence of higher-atmospheric CO2 pressure with relatively reasonable efficiency (Entries 1, 2). Modification of the catalyst to protic ILs allowed the reaction to proceed completely at high pressure or over a long time (Entries 3, 4). In the previous work [30], optimizing the type of protic hydrogen, the counter ion, as well as the length of the alkyl chain, made the intended reaction proceed well at 1 atm CO2 pressure within 2 h (Entries 5, 6). Since the study of protic ILs became widespread, a large number of them were synthesized and used for CO2 fixation into epoxide (Entries 7, 8). A study by Zhang and colleagues demonstrated that atmospheric CO2 can be used to synthesize carbonates in the presence of 4-substituted pyridine hydrobromide [39]. By introducing 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine into the reaction, the positive charge delocalized, thereby improving the reaction efficiency. Therefore, in order to advance the COCs synthesis reaction conditions, the previous IL catalyst was modified based on DMAP and compared with past works. In addition to all advantages mentioned in our previous work [30], the conversion and selectivity of the COCs formation reaction were significantly improved by using [CMDMAPy]Br as a catalyst under CO2 atmospheric pressure during 2.5 h. In optimal conditions and in the presence of a smaller amount of [CMDMAPy]Br as the catalyst, SC was obtained with 100% conversion, better selectivity, and higher TOF (h−1) (Entry 9). It can be concluded that the presence of acidic proton and nucleophilic counter ions are the key points for CO2 chemical fixation. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, in the continuation of protic ILs studies, a modified pyridinium IL, [CMDMAPy]Br, was synthesized and tested in COCs synthesis. DMAP acted as an IL's positive charge delocalizing agent as well as the physical transfer of CO2 into the liquid phase. The synergistic effects of DMAP, carboxylic acid group, and bromide anion made the reaction proceed well at CO2 atmospheric pressure for 2.5 h. The catalyst showed excellent efficiency in the solvent-free condition at 90 ˚C and in the presence of methanol at 65 ˚C without using any metal or co-catalysts. In the presence of [CMDMAPy]Br at 90 ֯C, under 1 atm CO2 pressure (CO2 balloon), and in solvent-free conditions, various terminal alkyl and aryl oxiranes were converted into their corresponding cyclic carbonates. The synthesized catalyst promoted the formation of COCs with higher conversion, selectivity, and TOF (h−1) than other previous ILs which indicated the great choice of pyridinium derivatives and halo acetic acid for IL synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Ionic liquids (ILs) are used as non-toxic, biodegradable, non-volatile, and relatively low-cost catalysts to synthesize 5-membered cyclic organic carbonates (COCs) from carbon dioxide (CO2) and different types of oxiranes in great conversion and selectivity. Single-component IL containing pyridinium salt moieties as quaternary amine, the carboxylic functional group as a H-bond donor, and bromine as a nucleophile and significant leaving group was synthesized by a simple method. The simultaneous selection and use of all mentioned factors in IL caused the epoxides converted into their corresponding carbonates under mild conditions, under 1 atm carbon dioxide (CO2) pressure (CO2 balloon), co-catalyst/ metal/ and solvent-free during 2.5 h. The synthetic catalyst converted styrene oxide (SO) to styrene carbonate (SC) with 100% conversion and selectivity. Moreover, the catalyst could be recycled more than four times before losing its remarkable catalytic activity. Finally, an inferential mechanism was suggested according to the experimental results.
coredata.dc:title: Acidic pyridinium ionic liquid: an efficient bifunctional organocatalyst to synthesis carbonate from atmospheric CO2 and epoxide.
